content.webTitle: Cricket: McGrath in race against time

fields.headline: McGrath gets Gladiator touch
fields.bodyText: "We had a pressing time-frame to get him fit, and a dedicated patient with good strength of character." So said the Australian cricket team's physio Errol Alcott - but he wasn't talking about his latest patient Glenn McGrath. In 2004, Alcott got a call from the actor (and cousin of New Zealand cricketing brothers) Russell Crowe, before the filming of the Ron Howard-directed movie Cinderella Man. Crowe had dislocated his shoulder and flew Alcott out to the film set in Toronto to work on him for the next five months. Alcott, a long-time employee of the Australian cricket team, had inevitably been recommended to Crowe by the Oscar-winner's buddy, Shane Warne. The physio is renowned for his "aggressive" (ie painful) style of treatment, but there were no further updates on McGrath's likely return date yesterday. · Lancashire were randomly drug-tested for the eighth time in 11 championship matches at Grace Road this week. And for the sixth of those eight times, Mal Loye was one of the two players randomly selected. Understandable, then, that Loye reacted brusquely when the tester approached him as he climbed the pavilion steps after a dubious lbw decision, saying: "I've got some more bad news for you . . ."
